entries.meaning: A supply of anything wasted or exhausted; a reinforcement.
A person enlisted for service in the army; a newly enlisted soldier.

examples: These new recruits were hired after passing the interviews

entries.meaning: (biology, ecology) A new adult or breeding-age member of a certain population.

verbs.description: recruit (third-person singular simple present recruits, present participle recruiting, simple past and past participle recruited)

entries.meaning: To enroll or enlist new members or potential employees on behalf of an employer, organization, sports team, the military, etc.
examples: We need to recruit more admin staff to deal with the massive surge in popularity of our products

entries.meaning: To supply with new men, as an army; to fill up or make up by enlistment; also, to muster
examples: the army was recruited for a campaign
they were looking to recruit two thousand troops for battle

entries.meaning: (archaic) To replenish, renew, or reinvigorate by fresh supplies; to remedy a lack or deficiency in.
examples: Her cheeks glow the brighter, recruiting their colour.

entries.meaning: (biology, intransitive) To become an adult or breeding-age member of a population.
(biochemistry) To prompt a protein, leucocyte. etc. to intervene in a given region of the body.
(dated, intransitive) To recuperate; to gain health, flesh, spirits, or the like.
examples: Lean cattle recruit in fresh pastures.
Go to the country to recruit.
